There are baffles or obstacles that the liquid has to navigate around before reaching the containers D and E.
Baffles are likely structures inside the container that change the direction of the fluid flow.
Baffles are commonly used in tanks and pipes to control the flow pattern, reduce turbulence, or promote mixing.

Baffles can block direct flow paths, so the liquid has to go around them.
Determine how each baffle affects the direction of the liquid flow.
Liquid will take the path of least resistance in the absence of external forces like gravity or pressure gradients.
In a system with baffles, the path is dictated by the baffle arrangement.
Consider the liquid as following a series of reflections off the baffles, similar to how light reflects off mirrors.
